result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Per EFV. arc

- Absolute sobriety:  Zero alcohol, zero controlled substances, zero prescribed medications (except as taken and prescribed for you by a physician) in your system, on your person, or in your possession at all times while this case is ongoing. This prohibition includes drug paraphernalia. Testing upon reasonable suspicion or at the Court's directive. All costs associated with testing shall be the responsibility of the defendant.

2:05 PM CO: SJN, RPR: V. Deiss, Clerk: B Harris,  Prosecuting attorney Karl E Anderson in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Melissa Marie Schlussler in court, in custody.  Attorney Jeremiah James Harrelson in court for Melissa Marie Schlussler. Includes 22CM386 (RW/INIT) & 22CF280 (RW).  Court reviews files.  DE makes statements as to why she missed court in 22CF280.  Court reinstates bond in 22CF280 and QUASHES WARRANT on 22CF280.  Court questions DE on missed attorney fees. DE responds.  Court does not reissue warrant for Atty fees.  On 22CM386- DE to contact PD to see if she qualifies, PFAC given to DE.  Court informs def of charges, possible penalties and rights. Def understands.  Waives reading.  NG. Court reserves rights.  State requests to set bond at $67 for restitution.
